results.title: Timothy Yu - Founder at Kilslaay Restaurant Group
results.content:
Timothy Yu
Founder at Kilslaay Restaurant Group
Vancouver
500 connections, 668 followers


About
I am a recent MBA grad with a dual specialization in Strategy, and Marketing. I achieved my MBA from the Sauder School of Business at UBC – where I was ranked in the top ten of my class – and at IE Business School in Madrid. I undertook the MBA in an effort to augment my creative aptitude with a more quantitative and critical skill set, and to gain a broader understanding of business strategy in general. 

I have a diverse marketing background with experience on both client and agency sides. I started my career working as a copywriter for Cossette Communications, and have since led a variety of cross-functional teams at a number of agencies. 

Most recently I worked for Vancouver startup, Recon Instruments and played a pivotal role in defining the marketing strategy and formulating the online community. 

I have an in-depth knowledge of both traditional and digital marketing platforms for B2C, and specialize in marketing and communication strategy creation for new media.

### Entrepreneur  
[Other](N/A)

N/A  
Toys, comics, books, collectables cards, stuffed animals, you name it, I’ve made it and ultimately sold it. Self-made, self-taught, and an entrepreneurial spirit that I’ve let run wild since the age of 14, has left me with a lifetime of lessons and memories. I certainly took the road less travelled, my own path has lead me to the unique position of owning multiple companies in the toy, licensing and publishing sectors. While each company is different in their own right, I believe that leadership starts at the top and I make it a point of emphasis to tailor the corporate culture to the type of team I’m building to help bring my visions to life.

results.title: Gary Hayes - Owner, Retail Adventure Inc.
results.content:
Gary Hayes
Owner, Retail Adventure Inc.
Pointe-Claire, Quebec, Canada
500 connections, 18052 followers


About
With a rich background in Canadian retailing, I have been at the forefront of innovative concepts that have left a lasting mark on the industry. One of my notable achievements was pioneering the BAYMART discount store concept at The Bay, long before the advent of Walmart in Canada. The success of BAYMART led to an expanded role, where I steered The Bay's foray into apparel, positioning it as a fashion leader in the 70's. Transitioning from department stores to specialty retail, I took on roles of increasing responsibility at Reitman's. As Vice President of Smart Set, and later as VP of Reitman's in the 80's, I introduced the groundbreaking in-season "item" repeat concept, a strategy that anticipated the "fast fashion" approach adopted by industry giants like Forever 21, H&M, and Zara. My journey then led me to Giant Tiger, where I devised and executed a robust fashion apparel strategy, fortifying GT against the challenges posed by Walmart. The events I orchestrated, including the PJ Party, Breast Cancer, Get Fit, Garden Party, and Canada Day celebrations, commanded a dominant presence in the market. I leverage my extensive experience in department stores, specialty retail, and discount stores to navigate the dynamic landscape of digital marketing. I know what has to be done on social media. My focus lies in evaluating retail strategies and uncovering emerging opportunities, all of which are meticulously documented in my weekly reports. THE REPORT: At the heart of my work is a weekly senior management report, meticulously crafted to unveil potential opportunities and highlight potential pitfalls. Armed with unfiltered information, this report empowers decision-makers to pose the right questions and allocate resources strategically to address the most pressing challenges.


Experience
Owner
[Retail Adventure Inc.](N/A)  
Jun 1999 - Present
Montreal, Quebec, Canada



Education
University of Oregon
Bachelor of Business Administration (B.B.A.), Marketing/Marketing Management, General
1959 - 1963
Activities and Societies: foreign students scholarship for academic excellence.

results.title: Dollarama
results.content:
Overview:
Dollarama was founded by third-generation retailer and Canadian entrepreneur, Larry Rossy. It all started with one store, in Matane, Quebec, in 1992, and quickly grew over the next two decades to become a household name and shopping destination for Canadians from coast to coast. Dollarama today is a recognized Canadian value retailer with well over 1,300 locations, led by Neil Rossy, fourth-generation retailer and member of Dollarama’s founding management team. Dollarama aims to provide customers with a consistent shopping experience and compelling value, offering a broad assortment of general merchandise, consumables and seasonal items. All stores are corporately-owned and operated, and are conveniently located in metropolitan areas, mid-sized cities and small towns. Products are available in individual or multiple units at low, fixed price points.

Dollarama was founded by third-generation retailer and Canadian entrepreneur, Larry Rossy. It all started with one store, in Matane, Quebec, in 1992, and quickly grew over the next two decades to become a household name and shopping destination for Canadians from coast to coast. Dollarama today is a recognized Canadian value retailer with well over 1,300 locations, led by Neil Rossy, fourth-generation retailer and member of Dollarama’s founding management team. Dollarama aims to provide customers with a consistent shopping experience and compelling value, offering a broad assortment of general merchandise, consumables and seasonal items. Restaurants Canada's President & CEO, [KELLY HIGGINSON](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/kelly-higginson-76668a1b?trk=public_post-text) has kicked things off for RC Show 2025 with her opening remarks at the Speaker Stage, and welcomed [Kim Wheatley](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/kim-wheatley-0bb089236?trk=public_post-text), Ojibwe Anishinaabe Grandmother from Shawanaga First Nation Reserve, who gave a beautiful performance and touching reminder that the culinary and restaurant trends of today stem from traditional wisdom. - Miigwech, Kim 🙏🏽

results.title: Restaurants Canada
results.content:
Overview:
Restaurants Canada is a national, not-for-profit member-based trade association advancing the potential of Canada’s diverse and dynamic foodservice industry through member programs, research, advocacy, resources and events. Canada’s foodservice sector is a $100 billion industry that serves 22 million customers across the country every day. As the fourth-largest private-sector employer, Canadian foodservice directly employs 1.2 million people and indirectly supports another 290,000+ jobs in related industries, with $32 billion in food and beverage products purchased every year. www.restaurantscanada.org

# Restaurants Canada
The voice of foodservice | La voix des services alimentaires
Non-profit Organizations • Toronto, Ontario • 37,784 followers • 11-50 employees

## Overview
Restaurants Canada is a national, not-for-profit member-based trade association advancing the potential of Canada’s diverse and dynamic foodservice industry through member programs, research, advocacy, resources and events. Canada’s foodservice sector is a $100 billion industry that serves 22 million customers across the country every day. As the fourth-largest private-sector employer, Canadian foodservice directly employs 1.2 million people and indirectly supports another 290,000+ jobs in related industries, with $32 billion in food and beverage products purchased every year. www.restaurantscanada.org

## Posts
**Restaurants Canada** (1d): Yesterday we had the pleasure of enjoying a delicious Osmow’s staff lunch—an extended celebration to congratulate the team on the re-opening of their original Streetsville location, the very spot where the Osmow's journey began over 20 years ago. Cheers to many more years of success! 🎉 👏 [Likes: 26, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (2d): Generations may differ, but they all matter. 51% of Millennials dine out weekly, compared to 35% of Boomers. Gen X spends the most at restaurants, and Gen Z is reshaping discovery through social media. Learn more and stay ahead — Start reading the 2025 Foodservice Facts report here: https://bit.ly/4nOzY0U #FoodserviceFacts2025 #Foodservice #Hospitality #data #consumertrends [Likes: 29, Comments: 0]; **Recipe Unlimited Corporation** (3d 4d Edited): We’re proud to share that our CEO, Frank Hennessey, has been honoured with a Lifetime Achievement Award at this year’s Rotman Alumni Awards. This recognition celebrates Frank’s remarkable leadership, vision, and impact on the Canadian restaurant industry and beyond. Throughout his career, Frank has not only guided Recipe through growth and transformation but has also inspired those around him with his commitment to people, innovation, and community. Congratulations, Frank, on this well-deserved honour! [Likes: 42, Comments: 0]; **Foodservice and Hospitality magazine** (3d): Mark von Schellwitz , Restaurants Canada ’s VP of Western Canada, has announced his retirement after more than 28 years with the organization. https://lnkd.in/gX9zey_F [Likes: 105, Comments: 85]; **Restaurants Canada** (3d): In this episode, we sit down with Chris Elliott , Chief Economist & Vice President, Research at Restaurants Canada, to unpack some of the biggest surprises from 2025: to explore the surprising 2025 sales rebound, how the GST holiday gave operators more than a breather, and why domestic tourism was the quiet hero keeping restaurants busy. Chris takes us behind the numbers—like why alcohol sales are slipping, why solo dining is on the rise, and how his POST strategy (Pricing, Operations, Staffing, Technology) can help operators tackle rising costs head-on. We also dig into the hot topics shaping menus and margins plus the real power of using data to make smarter moves. Most importantly, Chris shares why Foodservice Facts should be every operator’s secret weapon and gives us a peek into what’s ahead in 2026. Listen for: • Why sales are up—but profits aren’t • The hidden cost of ignoring productivity • What’s really changing on Canadian menus • How operators can use data to stay competitive 🎧 Tune in now on Spotify: https://bit.ly/42Yr9JV #MENUUnplugged #podcast #FoodserviceFacts #restaurants #data _____________________ 🎙️MENU Unplugged Podcast is a co-production of Restaurants Canada & Benchmark Sixty Restaurant Services 🎙️This episode sponsored by Groupex Canada [Likes: 4, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (4d): Restaurants Canada's 2025 Foodservice Facts report found that 8 in 10 young Canadians have cut back on restaurant spending because of rising living costs. Western Canada VP, Mark von Schellwitz joined CTV Vancouver to talk about what government can do to help Canadians struggling with affordability. Watch the full interview here: https://bit.ly/46KcCCC [Likes: 12, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (5d): It was a big week back in Ottawa for Restaurants Canada as we continued our conversations and lobby work around immigration, temporary foreign workers, removing GST from all food and strengthening the viability of the foodservice sector during this period of economic uncertainty. Our message is gaining traction—conversations with key decision-makers confirm they’re listening to our advocacy on affordability, workforce, and related issues. The response to our FOODISFOOD.CA campaign was very positive and gaining more interest. Additionally, we were able to share important context, real data and information on the use of temporary foreign workers. While this remains a complex issue for our sector, it’s essential we use these programs responsibly and continue to uphold the industry’s integrity and reputation. Read President & CEO, KELLY HIGGINSON 's full update here: https://bit.ly/42JsBje [Likes: 15, Comments: 1]; **Restaurants Canada** (1w): 🌍✈️Happy World Tourism Day! This year's theme, "Tourism and Sustainable Transformation," is a call to action for all of us. From coast to coast to coast, tourism is a powerful force that drives our economy, industry, celebrates our culture, and connects us with the world. Our vibrant food scene plays a massive role in this! Every time you dine at a local restaurant, you're not just enjoying a meal, you're supporting a network of local producers, farmers, fishers, and chefs. You're helping to sustain jobs and preserve the unique culinary traditions that define our diverse communities. 💡Fun Fact: The restaurant industry accounts for approximately one third of all tourism-related jobs—making it the largest employer within the tourism sector. #WorldTourismDay #SustainableTourism #ExploreCanada #SupportLocal [Likes: 11, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (1w): Restaurants Canada is deeply concerned about the nationwide strike launched by the Canadian Union of Postal Workers as Canadians and businesses cannot afford continued disruption. Read our full statement here: https://bit.ly/4myFELp [Likes: 4, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (1w): The Temporary Foreign Worker Program represents just 3% of the foodservice workforce, but it fills a critical need for rural, remote and tourism communities. Restaurants Canada's KELLY HIGGINSON joined CBC's Ontario Today to discuss the reality of the foodservice industry's workforce needs. Listen to the full episode here: https://bit.ly/46pSTJQ [Likes: 11, Comments: 1]

results.title: Temporary Foreign Worker program | Restaurants Canada ...
results.content: Restaurants Canada's President & CEO, KELLY HIGGINSON, sits down with Courtney Theriault to discuss the Leader of the Official Oppositions calls to scrap the Temporary Foreign Worker program. In response to the Leader of the Official Oppositions calls today to scrap the Temporary Foreign Worker program, Restaurants Canada says that without enough staff for key roles, restaurants in rural and remote communities risk reduced hours, closures, and lost local jobs. Click here to join Zoom: https://lnkd.in/g3D3Tpni Your views will be captured in a letter to the Federal Government addressing the need for immediate and responsible changes to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program to help deal with our labour shortages.

  In response to the Leader of the Official Oppositions calls today to scrap the Temporary Foreign Worker program, Restaurants Canada says that without enough staff for key roles, restaurants in rural and remote communities risk reduced hours, closures, and lost local jobs. Temporary Foreign Workers (TFWs), while making up only 3% of the foodservice workforce, play a vital role in sustaining operations in underserved areas. These workers: predominantly skilled chefs and cooks are often the cornerstone of a restaurants ability to operate and maintain operations. The realities of the aging labour market in many of these areas, means chefs and cooks are simply not available. Read our full statement here: [https://bit.ly/4p1XhG9](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit%2Ely%2F4p1XhG9&urlhash=l4W8&trk=public_post-text)

  ð£ð¨ Calling all members of BCs Restaurant Industry, Hotel Industry, Tourism, Distributors, Suppliers, Education providers, and industry stakeholders, Your BCRFA is taking the lead to gather voices from across industries to weigh in on our critical labour crisis. Tomorrow, Wednesday, September 10th, at 9 am, we are hosting an urgent meeting so that your voice can be heard. Click here to join Zoom: [https://lnkd.in/g3D3Tpni](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2Fg3D3Tpni&urlhash=2azh&trk=public_post-text) Your views will be captured in a letter to the Federal Government addressing the need for immediate and responsible changes to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program to help deal with our labour shortages. [Ian Tostenson](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/ian-tostenson-8530154?trk=public_post-text) will provide an update on recent events and discussions. We will then have open dialogue to get your feedback and comments so that we have this to take to the necessary levels of government. If you cannot attend, we kindly urge you to reach Ian by phone at 604.986.1429 or email at [itostenson@bcrfa.com](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=mailto%3Aitostenson%40bcrfa%2Ecom&urlhash=EMy2&trk=public_post-text) with your comments. Please forward to anyone in your network that may be interested in attending this. We are working to ensure government understands this critical shortage of skilled workers is already devastating a multitude of industries. If meaningful changes to allow responsible access to needed workers do not come quickly, the effects are going to be sweeping and irreversible.

  More stark statistics from the latest Scottish Licensed Trade Association survey. 350 businesses (bars, pubs, restaurants and hotels) across Scotland. 75% are less profitable in the first half of 2025 than they were in 2024, with 14% considering closing altogether. 56% saw their profits dip by more than 10%. The current trading conditions are brutal. Increases to employers NICs were found to have had a massive impact on respondents businesses. 32% forced to reduce staffing. 19% have had to cut their trading hours. Changes to VAT and business rates were the most commonly requested measures from respondents to the Westminster and Holyrood governments [The Scottish Tourism Alliance The restaurant industry is such an incredibly diverse and multicultural sector of our economy, a critical employer of new Canadians, and home to entrepreneurs who have come to Canada and started businesses from every part of the world.

results.content:
Michael Lovsin
Global Executive, Retail, CPG, President, CEO & Board Member
Canada
500 connections, 4810 followers


About
Passionate about people. Strategic, innovative and transformational leader that delivers results. Empathetic communicator and listener leveraging over 35 years of Retail and CPG experience. Customer-centric, entrepreneurial , business building coach and mentor who thrives on delivering beyond customer expectations. Pragmatic approach to work and life, and conducts business with integrity. • Strategy Development and Business Innovation • Building and leading diverse teams • Sales Planning and Category Management • CPG,Product Development & Private Label • P&L Management • Merchandising Execution • Collaborative Vendor Management & Negotiations Business Expertise in: Retail, Drugstore/Pharmacy, Cosmetics/Beauty, Health & Wellness, Grocery, Natural Foods, CPG and Private Label


Experience
President and CEO
[Brilliant Ideas Group Canada](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/brilliant-ideas-group-canada)  
Jul 2017 - Present
Toronto, Canada Area
Helping companies from around the world establish their businesses in North America. Brilliant Ideas Group (BIG, for short) is a boutique consulting agency and brand growth engine that generates strategic business results. We are all about thinking BIG but being realistic in our objectives and approach. We set out to create something special by helping companies to build better brands, products and relationships with retailers and customers alike. 

BIG inspires new ways of thinking and doing to achieve brand growth and success. We help bring brilliant ideas, brands and services to life with a focus on natural and sustainable. Central to our approach is the voice of the customer and how we can make a difference and deliver beyond their expectations.

https://www.brilliantideasgroup.ca/


Education
Schulich School of Business - York University
N/A
N/A - Present
None

# Michael Lovsin **Global Executive, Retail, CPG, President, CEO & Board Member** Canada, CA 500 connections, 4810 followers ## About Passionate about people

Strategic, innovative and transformational leader that delivers results

Empathetic communicator and listener leveraging over 35 years of Retail and CPG experience

Customer-centric, entrepreneurial , business building coach and mentor who thrives on delivering beyond customer expectations

Pragmatic approach to work and life, and conducts business with integrity

• Strategy Development and Business Innovation • Building and leading diverse teams • Sales Planning and Category Management • CPG,Product Development & Private Label • P&L Management • Merchandising Execution • Collaborative Vendor Management & Negotiations Business Expertise in: Retail, Drugstore/Pharmacy, Cosmetics/Beauty, Health & Wellness, Grocery, Natural Foods, CPG and Private Label ## Experience ### President and CEO [Brilliant Ideas Group Canada](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/brilliant-ideas-group-canada) Jul 2017 - Present Toronto, Canada Area Helping companies from around the world establish their businesses in North America. Brilliant Ideas Group (BIG, for short) is a boutique consulting agency and brand growth engine that generates strategic business results. We are all about thinking BIG but being realistic in our objectives and approach. We set out to create something special by helping companies to build better brands, products and relationships with retailers and customers alike. BIG inspires new ways of thinking and doing to achieve brand growth and success. We help bring brilliant ideas, brands and services to life with a focus on natural and sustainable. Central to our approach is the voice of the customer and how we can make a difference and deliver beyond their expectations. https://www.brilliantideasgroup.ca/ ### Managing Director North America [BWX Limited](https://au.linkedin.com/company/bwx-limited) Jan 2020 - Dec 2020 Petaluma, California BWX is doing things differently. With an increasing number of people worldwide making the switch to natural, our brands are perfectly positioned to capitalise on this consumer wellness movement. Natural products not only offer toxin-free solutions, but with advancements in natural ingredient technology are setting new standards in performance. ### General Manager Coles Brands [Coles](https://au.linkedin.com/company/colesgroup) Apr 2015 - Jun 2017 Melbourne, Australia Coles Supermarkets is Australias second largest supermarket retailer. Coles provides fresh food, groceries, general merchandise, liquor, fuel, and financial services to more than 21 million customers on average each week, through its store network and online platform. Coles has more than 100,000 team members and operates more than 2400 retail outlets. Responsible for Coles Brand with annual sales exceeding 8 billion and the largest consumer package brand in Australia. Led, coached and mentored a team of 150 dedicated team members across product development, innovation, technology, design and packaging. Accountable for creation, development and execution of vision and strategy for Coles Brand, reporting to the CCO. ### Loblaw Companies Limited [Loblaw Companies Limited](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/loblaw-companies-limited?trk=public_profile_experience-group-header) N/A - Present Brampton, Ontario.Canada ### Vice President Merchandising [ULTA Beauty](https://www.linkedin.com/company/ulta) Feb 2005 - Oct 2006 Greater Chicago Area Responsible for Prestige Cosmetics and Skincare, Store Concept and Design, Category Management including planograms, Merchandising and Training and Development teams. An Officer of the company reporting directly to the President and CEO. Steering Committee Member responsible for developing, reviewing and implementing corporate strategies and organizational vision. ### Shoppers Drug Mart [Shoppers Drug Mart](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/shoppers-drug-mart?trk=public_profile_experience-group-header) N/A - Present Toronto, Canada Area ## Education ### Schulich School of Business - York University N/A N/A - Present None ## Publications **The 10 biggest marketing stories of 2015** The Sydney Morning Herald • Published on December 30, 2015 **Coles Radically Consolidates & Reinvents Private Brand** My Private Brand • Published on November 23, 2015 **Aldi threat sees Coles revamp home brands** The Australian • Published on November 19, 2015 **Parcel delivery innovation: empowering the customer** Canadian Grocer • Published on August 29, 2014 **Can technology solve out of stocks, on shelf availability?** Canadian Grocer • Published on May 1, 2014 **What’s the next consumer trend? Look no further than low GI** Canadian Grocer • Published on January 24, 2014 **Making supermarkets the hub of health care** Canadian Grocer • Published on May 29, 2013 **Canadian Grocer** Canada • Published on Apr 2013 **Ontario's Healthy Kids Panel** Ontario Government • Published on May 18, 2012 **IHR Magazine - November / December Issue 2011** IHR Magazine • Published on January 9, 2012 ## Honors & Awards N/A ## Certifications N/A ## Volunteering N/A ## Languages N/A ## Organizations N/A ## Activity - **just dropped Woolworths Supermarkets 🇦🇺 first ♡Gluten-Free ♡Plant-Based ♡ Protein wafer bars 🎤 🚀 lets go** Liked by Michael Lovsin [View Post](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mattdemicoli_just-dropped-woolworths-supermarkets-activity-7382979154264252416-s05J) ![Activity Image](https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/D5622AQF_ywygPPl9Aw/feedshare-shrink_2048_1536/B56ZnWcad0JQAw-/0/1760239397738?e=2147483647&v=beta&t=I93jjOMSN7pR0L74rW13pdiwWU9sOSCIJbYodgE4Zg0) - **ICYMI 🚀 The Good Collective™ Organic Vitamins are here! results.title: Dan Holman - Business Owner | Speaker | Implementer
results.content:
Dan Holman
Business Owner | Speaker | Implementer | Retail Mentor | Consultant I Trainer
St Albert, Alberta, Canada
500 connections, 1600 followers


About
Dan has spent more than 30 years in the retail and service industries. Specializing in marketing & business development, inventory planning, operations and customer driven sales management. He is an award-winning business coach with a proven understanding of what it takes to be successful as an entrepreneur. Dan spent 16 years in senior management and ownership roles with multi-store retailers before joining Canadian Retail Solutions as their CEO, Director of Retail Planning. Dan works directly with clients’ coast to coast representing hundreds of retail categories. He is the founder of The Wealthy Retailer™ which began as an educational series delivering a successive in-depth look at key areas for growing and nurturing retail stores to maximize their profit potential.


Experience
CEO, Director of Retail Planning
[Canadian Retail Solutions Inc.](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/canadian-retail-solutions-inc.)  
Apr 2016 - Present
Canada



Education
N/A
results.raw_content:
# Dan Holman **Business Owner | Speaker | Implementer | Retail Mentor | Consultant I Trainer** St Albert, Alberta, Canada, CA 500 connections, 1600 followers ## About Dan has spent more than 30 years in the retail and service industries

Specializing in marketing & business development, inventory planning, operations and customer driven sales management

He is an award-winning business coach with a proven understanding of what it takes to be successful as an entrepreneur

Dan spent 16 years in senior management and ownership roles with multi-store retailers before joining Canadian Retail Solutions as their CEO, Director of Retail Planning

Dan works directly with clients’ coast to coast representing hundreds of retail categories

He is the founder of The Wealthy Retailer™ which began as an educational series delivering a successive in-depth look at key areas for growing and nurturing retail stores to maximize their profit potential

results.raw_content:
### Retail General Manager

[Staples Canada](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/staples-canada?trk=public_jobs_sub-nav-cta-optional-url "Staples Canada") Newmarket, Ontario, Canada

# Retail General Manager

#### [Staples Canada](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/staples-canada?trk=public_jobs_topcard-org-name) Newmarket, Ontario, Canada 1 month ago 90 applicants [See who Staples Canada has hired for this role](https://www.linkedin.com/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fsearch%2Fresults%2Fpeople%2F%3FfacetCurrentCompany%3D3020%26title%3DRetail%2BGeneral%2BManager&emailAddress=&fromSignIn=&trk=public_jobs_see-who-was-hired_people-search-link_face-pile-cta)

* [Report this job](https://www.linkedin.com/uas/login?fromSignIn=true&session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fca.linkedin.com%2Fjobs%2Fview%2Fretail-general-manager-at-staples-canada-4289942774&trk=public_jobs_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=JOB&_f=guest-reporting)

**Job Description****Some of what you will do**We are seeking a dynamic and strategic General Manager to lead our retail operations team and drive operational excellence. As a General Manager, you will champion our selling model, inspire a customer-first mentality, and foster a culture of continuous improvement. Your leadership will be pivotal in achieving business and financial results, developing talent, and enhancing customer experiences.**Specifically, you will**

* Drive Operational and Sales Excellence: Model and nurture our sales culture to add value for our customers. Oversee all aspects of Brand Standards and implement continuous improvement initiatives.
* Leadership: Lead by example and with purpose, motivate and empower your team, and inspire exceptional customer service. Execute day-to-day floor leadership duties, making confident and purposeful decisions.
* Strategic Vision: Develop and execute a strategic vision to promote a customer-first mentality within the team. Inspire and work through your entire store team to bring this vision to life.
* Financial Management: Achieve business and financial targets by monitoring budgets, analyzing reports, and making informed decisions.
* Business Development: Identify and pursue business development opportunities, partner with customers for B2B solutions, and drive sales conversion.
* People Management: Manage scheduling, coach and develop talent, recruit top talent, and nurture employee engagement. Create an environment in which you and your team focus on development as a priority.
* Communication: Disseminate business communications, initiatives, and results. Act as a change leader and ensure transparency.
* Health & Safety: Ensure compliance for all aspects of Health & Safety, Asset Protection (AP), Privacy, and company policies and procedures.

**Some Of What You Need**

* 3-5 years of experience in a retail management role. Preferably as a General Manager.
* Proven experience with achieving sales and service targets with a customer-centered approach.
* Ability to lead in a fast-paced environment with strong prioritization, organization, and multi-tasking skills.
* Excellent communication and interpersonal skills, people are inspired by your communication.
* Experience in coaching, developing talent, and managing teams.

**Some Of What You Will Get**

* Associate discount
* Health and dental benefits
* Competitive PTO; Personal Days
* RRSP/DPSP program
* Performance bonus
* Learning & Development programs
* And more...

#WorkLearnGrow1**About Us**Staples Canada is an equal opportunity employer committed to diversity and inclusion and we encourage applications from all qualified candidates, including those with disabilities.**About The Team****About the Team**At Staples Canada we are dynamic, inspiring partners to our customers and the communities in which we live. As The Working and Learning Company, we inspire people to work smarter, learn more and grow every day. We’re looking for curious, approachable, and passionate individuals who love finding solutions. If that’s you, let’s work, learn, and grow together.**We are building an inclusive and diverse team**Staples Canada is continuously working towards creating an inclusive and diverse work environment. We welcome, value and thrive on perspectives and contributions from backgrounds that vary by race, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, lifestyle, age, educational background, national origin, religion or physical ability. If you have a disability or special need that requires accommodation, please let us know.

* ### Seniority level

   Mid-Senior level
* ### Employment type

   Full-time
* ### Job function

   Sales and Business Development
* ### Industries

   Retail

results.title: Chris Meyer - Co-founder and Managing Partner ...
results.content:
Chris Meyer
Co-founder and Managing Partner FORELEFT HOSPITALITY LTD.
Canada
500 connections, 1722 followers


About
Hospitality executive and entrepreneur with over 25 years of leadership experience across Canada and the U.S., guiding restaurants, breweries, and distilleries through growth, transformation, and operational excellence. As Co-Founder and Owner of Foreleft Hospitality, I helped build and operate four distinct concepts in British Columbia—Noble at the Hills, Wayback Brew Co., Resurrection Spirits, and FRANKS Pizza & Bar—under one scalable operational and financial structure. My approach combines strategic vision with hands-on execution, enabling brand growth, team development, and exceptional guest experiences. Previously, as Vice President of Operations for CFW Group, I led a diverse portfolio spanning Joe Forte’s, The Shore Club, Ki Modern Japanese, Fleetwood’s on Front Street (Maui), and The Grill on the Alley (California). Managing over 500 employees across multiple regions, I gained extensive international operational expertise, navigating complex compliance and labor environments in competitive markets like California. My leadership style is data-driven yet people-focused: I believe that profitability and employee engagement thrive together when strategy, systems, and culture align. I excel at scaling brands, building strong teams, and delivering consistent results in dynamic hospitality landscapes.

# Chris Meyer **Co-founder and Managing Partner FORELEFT HOSPITALITY LTD.** Canada, CA 500 connections, 1722 followers ## About Hospitality executive and entrepreneur with over 25 years of leadership experience across Canada and the U

S

, guiding restaurants, breweries, and distilleries through growth, transformation, and operational excellence

As Co-Founder and Owner of Foreleft Hospitality, I helped build and operate four distinct concepts in British Columbia—Noble at the Hills, Wayback Brew Co

, Resurrection Spirits, and FRANKS Pizza & Bar—under one scalable operational and financial structure

My approach combines strategic vision with hands-on execution, enabling brand growth, team development, and exceptional guest experiences

Previously, as Vice President of Operations for CFW Group, I led a diverse portfolio spanning Joe Forte’s, The Shore Club, Ki Modern Japanese, Fleetwood’s on Front Street (Maui), and The Grill on the Alley (California)

Managing over 500 employees across multiple regions, I gained extensive international operational expertise, navigating complex compliance and labor environments in competitive markets like California

My leadership style is data-driven yet people-focused: I believe that profitability and employee engagement thrive together when strategy, systems, and culture align

I excel at scaling brands, building strong teams, and delivering consistent results in dynamic hospitality landscapes

## Experience ### Business Owner [Foreleft Hospitality LTD](N/A) Apr 2024 - Present South Surrey Founder ### Business Owner [Wayback Brewing Co.](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/wayback-brewing-co) Jun 2023 - Present Surrey, British Columbia, Canada Craft Brewery | Tap Room ### Business Owner [Resurrection Spirits](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/resurrection-spirits) Jun 2023 - Present Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada ### Executive Vice President [The CFW Group](N/A) Jun 2019 - Mar 2023 Vancouver/ Whistler/ Los Angeles/ Maui Responsible for all business operations for a boutique hospitality brand with 800 employees and $40M in revenue and well-known locations in Vancouver, Whistler, Beverly Hills ,Thousand Oaks, CA, and Maui, HI. More specifically, I lead, analyzed and executed operations strategy and process, coordinating with the executive team. I championed the company’s expectations, goals, and core values across locations as a Brand Ambassador. I nourished the soul of each restaurant and impart the vision and ambience whether a Hollywood hangout or a rich Republic. During Covid, I retrained in new methodologies and maintained a casual “come back when you are ready” flair, providing comfort and empathy to patrons. A few measurables include: • I sustained a $17M revenue stream at Joe Fortes, an award-winning boutique restaurant in Vancouver, and an increase to $19M post pandemic - $5M revenue increase in the first 3 years as Director at Fleetwood’s on Front Street a coastal restaurant in Maui, HI. In addition, I oversaw acquisitions and onboardings of multiple new boutique restaurants in Los Angeles, functioning as project lead, creating 1st year positive sales growth. I also opened a second Joe Fortes location in Whistler, BC as project lead. ### Managing Director [Fleetwood's on Front Street](N/A) Apr 2017 - Mar 2023 Lahaina, Hawaii ### General Manager [Joe Fortes Seafood & Chop House](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/joe-fortes-seafood-&-chop-house) Apr 2017 - Jun 2019 N/A During these few years before accepting a larger role, I oversaw day-to-day business operations for two CFW Group Locations: Joe Fortes, Vancouver, and Fleetwoods, Maui. I created financial reports for the regional office and liaised between facility operators and the home office. I managed all property level projects and teams. In more detail, I rebuilt and reenergized Fleetwood’s on Front, a coastal restaurant in Maui, HI, augmenting the leadership team, reorganizing the existing P&L structure, and re-strategizing the business to cater to the tourism industry. I rescued this operation from an embezzlement situation, fired leadership, and rebuilt the management team. I implemented new standards, creating an exciting culture and a hot venue for hotel concierges. I also leveraged exceptional communication and interpersonal skills, leading and mentoring an experienced team of managers at both locations, overseeing over 300 team members. I executed regular visitations and audits at each property, collaborating directly with property level teams to provide guidance and ongoing action reports. Lastly, I turned around a demoralizing, harassment ridden culture through instituting high expectations and hiring top talent. ### General Manager [ki modern japanese + bar](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/ki-modern-japanese---bar) Mar 2016 - Jun 2017 Toronto, Canada Area During this fast-paced year, I oversaw all day-to-day business operations for KI Modern Japanese, a $9M restaurant in Toronto, Ontario. I quickly but effectively sourced and seated restaurant managers and authored and executed location-specific strategic business plans. I turned over all but one in leadership, after a neglect in previous oversight and kept an amazing, passionate staff. I rebuilt and developed the restaurant team, implementing incentives for employee development. I oversaw the tricky synchronization of a hot kitchen and sushi bar with unique ingredients. I also recreated a respect for leadership from staff, learning the Japanese craft and brand and being a servant leader. results.title: Aimy Boisvert - Co-Founder - CEO @ Me N ü Helping ...
results.content:
Aimy Boisvert
Co-Founder - CEO @ Me N ü Helping foodies and restaurants “click” together. 📲🍴
Canada
500 connections, 511 followers


About
Ceo of an early startup called Me N ü. My journey started with Ventilaction2000, a family business serving restaurants and other industrial businesses since 1996. Working closely with the restaurant community sparked a desire to make a positive change in Montreal's dining scene and to bring people together. With a background in management and insights from the industry, our beautiful tech team and I founded Me N ü, a mobile app designed to enhance dining experiences. After the pandemic, it was even more obvious that our company's goal was to bring people back in the dinning room. This app is a humble effort to help restaurants connect in a simple way with their clients. From Ventilaction2000 to Me N ü, my journey continues to be fueled by the deep desire to unite people at the table. Imagine: Me N ü, creating a more delightful and innovative dining adventure for everyone, one byte at the time. We make dinning experience fun for foodies and offer cool features through our app and software. Let’s make the dining experience as smooth as your crème brûlée 🍮


Experience
Founder
[Me N ü](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/theappmenu)  
Sep 2020 - Present
Canada
Hey there, I'm Aimy Boisvert, and I'm absolutely thrilled to be part of the Me N ü adventure as founder and CEO. My journey has been all about pairing my appreciation for technology with my love for the art of food. This is where the magic happens – where innovation meets gastronomy.


Starting out, I saw the potential at the intersection of food and easy tech for restaurants!

Me N ü is a platform that aspires to connect foodies with our beloved restaurants.


Education
Collège de Maisonneuve
Business Administration and Management, General
N/A - Present
None

Richmond, British Columbia, Canada
500 connections, 2071 followers


About
From a culinary & operations executive to a co-founder of an online food hub & private kitchen space. My passion is in building and creating.


Experience
Co-Founder | CEO of MOD KITCHEN
[MOD Kitchen](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/mod-kitchen)  
Mar 2022 - Present
Richmond, British Columbia, Canada
At MOD Kitchen, we are redefining the restaurant industry by providing state-of-the-art cloud kitchen spaces designed to support restaurant owners in expanding their reach and maximizing operational efficiency. As CEO, I oversee all aspects of operations, from strategic planning to daily management, ensuring our clients receive unparalleled support and resources.


Vision & Leadership: Co-founded MOD Kitchen, a pioneering concept aimed at bringing together 10 state-of-the-art kitchens under one roof, specifically designed for takeout and delivery orders.


Operational Planning: Developed comprehensive operational strategies and processes to ensure the highest standards of hygiene and food safety for a fully licensed and professionally equipped facility.


Innovative Solutions: Conceptualized and planned the cloud kitchen model to optimize logistics and streamline operations, addressing the growing demand for convenient, contactless food delivery.


Community Engagement: Engaged with local food entrepreneurs to understand their needs and challenges, fostering strong relationships to support Richmond’s diverse food culture.


Infrastructure Development: Led the planning and development of MOD Kitchen’s infrastructure, ensuring all kitchens are designed with world-class equipment and tailored for operational efficiency.


Team Building: Recruited and established a collaborative and trust-first environment with vendors and partners.


Education
Vancouver Community College
Culinary, Culinary Arts/Chef Training
N/A - Present
None

results.title: Chris Meyer - Co-founder and Managing Partner ...
results.content:
Chris Meyer
Co-founder and Managing Partner FORELEFT HOSPITALITY LTD.
Canada
500 connections, 1722 followers


About
Hospitality executive and entrepreneur with over 25 years of leadership experience across Canada and the U.S., guiding restaurants, breweries, and distilleries through growth, transformation, and operational excellence. As Co-Founder and Owner of Foreleft Hospitality, I helped build and operate four distinct concepts in British Columbia—Noble at the Hills, Wayback Brew Co., Resurrection Spirits, and FRANKS Pizza & Bar—under one scalable operational and financial structure. My approach combines strategic vision with hands-on execution, enabling brand growth, team development, and exceptional guest experiences. Previously, as Vice President of Operations for CFW Group, I led a diverse portfolio spanning Joe Forte’s, The Shore Club, Ki Modern Japanese, Fleetwood’s on Front Street (Maui), and The Grill on the Alley (California). Managing over 500 employees across multiple regions, I gained extensive international operational expertise, navigating complex compliance and labor environments in competitive markets like California. My leadership style is data-driven yet people-focused: I believe that profitability and employee engagement thrive together when strategy, systems, and culture align. I excel at scaling brands, building strong teams, and delivering consistent results in dynamic hospitality landscapes.

More specifically, I lead, analyzed and executed operations strategy and process, coordinating with the executive team. I championed the company’s expectations, goals, and core values across locations as a Brand Ambassador. I nourished the soul of each restaurant and impart the vision and ambience whether a Hollywood hangout or a rich Republic. During Covid, I retrained in new methodologies and maintained a casual “come back when you are ready” flair, providing comfort and empathy to patrons. A few measurables include: • I sustained a $17M revenue stream at Joe Fortes, an award-winning boutique restaurant in Vancouver, and an increase to $19M post pandemic - $5M revenue increase in the first 3 years as Director at Fleetwood’s on Front Street a coastal restaurant in Maui, HI. I implemented new standards, creating an exciting culture and a hot venue for hotel concierges. # 10 Innovative Canadian Small Businesses: Blueprints for Entrepreneurial Success

* [Report this article](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2F10-innovative-canadian-small-businesses-wa7tc&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=PONCHO_ARTICLE&_f=guest-reporting)

[CanadianSME Small Business Magazine](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/canadiansme-business-magazine) 

### CanadianSME Small Business Magazine

#### Empowering Canadian Small and Medium Enterprises,

Published Oct 28, 2024

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2F10-innovative-canadian-small-businesses-wa7tc&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

There’s no denying that small businesses are the economic backbone of Canada, without which our overall progress as a nation can come to an abrupt standstill. As such, to honour and acknowledge their significant contributions to our great country, pivoting its progress one start-up at a time, we have selected the 10 most exceptional small businesses thriving and transforming their industries on the occasion of commemorating October as Small Business Month all over Canada. These companies are exemplary for their out-of-the-box approach to making a difference in their niche industries, serving as practical case studies for entrepreneurs to learn from nationwide. Thus, this write-up is all about recognizing the individual efforts of some of the emerging businesses in the Canadian market. Here’s a rundown of all those companies; let’s dive in.

Rootd (Victoria, BC)

Key Insight: Tackling a widespread issue of mental health through an accessible solution that has the potential to foster swift expansion and worldwide influence.

Rootd is a tech startup from British Columbia that has stirred the competitive mental health app market. Founded by Ania Wysocka, the company has leveraged the power of Canadian innovation to become the top-ranked app for panic attacks and anxiety relief on both the App Store and Google Play. What’s more, its USP lies in its user-friendly interface and compelling features.

Notably, Rootd’s success with over 2 million downloads and 50,000+ user reviews demonstrates the potential for Canadian businesses to scale globally. The app’s simple approach to mental health support, including a panic button, guided breathing exercises, and journaling tools, showcases the power of combining simplicity with effectiveness. In fact, Rootd’s expansion into B2B partnerships emphasizes the importance of diversifying revenue streams and exploring multiple market segments for small business owners.

To learn more about Rootd’s simple yet effective solutions for controlling anxiety and panic attacks, click [here.](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Erootd%2Eio%2F%23signup&urlhash=Mb96&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block)

Still North Design Co. (Whitehorse, Yukon)

Key Insight: When local inspiration projects a global appeal by combining quality and authenticity with stellar customer service.

The Whitehorse-based Still North Design Co. has catapulted Yukon to the international platform of high fashion. Owner and founder Courtney Vreeman has adeptly turned her northern-inspired designs into a clothing and lifestyle brand that connects with customers throughout Canada and beyond.

Still North’s success story is lesson 101 on how to leverage your unique local identity to create a high-value business brand. Their product line, which includes everything from cozy hoodies to distinctive accessories, captures the essence of Canada’s North. This approach has allowed Still North to carve out a niche in the crowded apparel market. With an unwavering commitment to quality and customer service, Still North offers truly unique fashion pieces. In the world of true Canadian fashion, the company goes above and beyond to ensure customer satisfaction, building a loyal following beyond Yukon’s borders.

Ultimately, Still North’s journey shows businesses how important it is to be genuine while branding their products. This illustrates how small-town businesses can utilize e-commerce and social media to connect with a worldwide audience. The company’s success in international markets demonstrates that “Made in Canada” can be a compelling selling point when paired with authentic quality and service.

Wanna explore Still North’s clothing line? Click [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fstillnorthdesignco%2Eca%2Fcollections%2Fall-products%3Fpage%3D2&urlhash=4q6e&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) to learn more.

Kekuli Café (West Kelowna, BC)

Key Insight: A haven of baked delights where cultural heritage is a significant differentiator in a competitive market, particularly when integrated with a franchising model.

Kekuli Café, co-founded by Sharon Bond-Hogg and Darren Hogg, draws pure joy in serving patrons with its delicious bannock while providing a glimpse into Canadian Indigenous culture. With its popular tagline, “Don’t Panic… We Have Bannock!” and a menu featuring a variety of bannock-based dishes inspired by Indigenous flavours, Kekuli Café has created a unique brand identity that resonates with a diverse customer base. What’s more, the business model promotes Indigenous entrepreneurship and preserves culinary heritage by creating job prospects for Indigenous communities across Canada through its franchising plans.

Kekuli Café’s success illustrates the potential of cultural authenticity as a distinctive selling proposition for small business proprietors. Plus, not only does it demonstrate how franchising can be an effective strategy for scaling a business, but it also maintains brand integrity. The café’s strong commitment to sourcing from Indigenous suppliers shows how companies can create positive ripple effects in their communities, inspiring entrepreneurs to value their cultural heritage and benefit the larger community.

Check out Kekuli Cafe’s delectable menu and the wholesome energy they serve with their hot beverages. Click [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Ekekulicafe%2Ecom%2F&urlhash=07KP&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) for more information.

Smart Dolphins IT Solutions (Victoria, BC)

Key Insight: Achieving long-term success in the tech sector requires adapting to evolving client needs, anticipating industry trends, and cultivating a culture of ongoing learning.

Led by Dave Monahan, Smart Dolphins IT Solutions has been delivering proactive IT services for more than 16 years. The company’s distinctive ‘pod’ system allocates a dedicated team to every client, guaranteeing tailored and thorough support. In fact, they help small and medium-sized enterprises with cybersecurity, cloud solutions, and IT strategy planning. Being one of Canada’s Top 100 Solution Providers, Smart Dolphins’ several accolades and certifications attest to the company’s dedication to lifelong learning.

As a matter of fact, Smart Dolphins provides valuable lessons in developing a sustainable business, particularly for entrepreneurs in technology-related disciplines. The company’s success emphasizes the significance of creating a culture of innovation, investing in employee skills, and remaining informed about industry developments. It illustrates how a business can distinguish itself in a competitive market by emphasizing personalized service and client relationships.

Visit Smart Dolphin’s official website [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Esmartdolphins%2Ecom%2F&urlhash=v-Af&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) to learn more about its innovative solutions for Canadian small businesses.

MedEssist (Toronto, ON)

Key Insight: Technology has the potential to revolutionize traditional industries by tackling enduring challenges and enhancing accessibility, especially in essential services such as healthcare.

With its cutting-edge platform, Toronto-based MedEssist—founded by Joella Almeida and Michael Do—is transforming the pharmaceutical industry. What’s more, the healthcare startup streamlines prescription management and patient communication, allowing pharmacists to focus more on patient care. With its multilingual capabilities and user-friendly interface catering to Canada’s diverse population, MedEssist is truly setting it apart in the market.

In fact, the above statement has been proven right with MedEssist’s recent recognition as one of the Top 10 startups in Calgary—an achievement that underscores its potential to reshape healthcare delivery. The company’s success story highlights the importance of addressing industry challenges, leveraging technology for improved service delivery, and considering diversity and inclusion in product development.

To know more about MedEssist’s services, visit their official site [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Emedessist%2Ecom%2F&urlhash=ZqT8&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block).

Neo Financial (Calgary, AB)

Key Insight: Disrupting conventional banking through cutting-edge digital solutions, which have the potential to capture a substantial market share.

Neo Financial, established by Andrew Chau and Jeff Adamson, who are also the co-founders of SkipTheDishes, is altering the financial services landscape in Canada. Not only has this Calgary-based fintech startup quickly become a formidable challenger to traditional banks by offering digital-first financial products, but its offerings include high-interest savings accounts, cashback credit cards, and investment opportunities, all managed through a sleek, user-friendly app. However, what truly sets Neo apart is its innovative partnership approach, which creates a unique rewards ecosystem that benefits consumers and businesses.

As a matter of fact, the company’s rapid growth is a testament to the demand for more flexible, transparent, and customer-centric financial services, which is why Neo Financial’s success underscores the potential for disruption in even the most established industries and serves as an exemplary case study for entrepreneurs. It also highlights the importance of leveraging technology to create seamless user experiences and building strategic partnerships to enhance value propositions.

Click [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eneofinancial%2Ecom%2F&urlhash=5awy&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) to learn more about Neo Financial’s solutions and upcoming products.

Zeno Renewables (Calgary, AB)

Key Insight: Connecting business objectives with broader social movements to help foster growth, thereby attracting exceptional talent.

Zeno Renewables, co-founded by Gursh Bal and Kai Fahrion, is leading Canada’s shift towards sustainable energy. Armed with the mission to install solar solutions on 1 million homes by 2040, positioning itself as more than just a business—it’s a movement towards a greener future.

In fact, the company’s approach goes beyond simply installing solar panels — as they offer comprehensive energy solutions, including energy storage systems and smart home integrations, making renewable energy more accessible and practical for homeowners.

It is also worth noting that their concept has positively impacted Canada’s energy business scene, and Zeno’s co-CEOs were recognized in Avenue Magazine’s Calgary Top 40 Under 40. Zeno’s success serves as a compelling example for small business owners, highlighting the impact of establishing bold goals that resonate with global trends. This demonstrates how a clear mission can attract top talent and media attention, crucial for scaling a business in a competitive market.

To learn more about Zeno’s renewable energy solutions, visit the [link here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elivezeno%2Ecom%2F&urlhash=qs3J&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block).

ChargeLab (Toronto, ON)

Key Insight: Creating scalable solutions for emerging markets which have the potential to draw considerable investment and foster partnerships.

ChargeLab plays a crucial role in the electric vehicle (EV) revolution by developing scalable EV charging solutions. Established by Zak Lefevre, this Toronto-based startup is tackling an essential demand in the swiftly expanding EV market.

Speaking of their tech prowess, ChargeLab’s software platform enables businesses to deploy, manage, and scale EV charging infrastructure efficiently. Their technology is hardware-agnostic, allowing for integration with various charging station manufacturers and providing a unified management system for operators.

The company’s recent $15 million financing boost demonstrates investors’ confidence in its ability to influence the future of transportation infrastructure. ChargeLab’s journey is a valuable lesson for entrepreneurs, emphasizing the significance of recognizing and tackling pain points within emerging industries. This highlights how creating adaptable, scalable solutions can enable a small business to overgrow and attract considerable investment.

To learn more about ChargeLab’s solutions, click [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchargelab%2Eco%2F&urlhash=qYE0&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) to navigate to their official website.

Alvéole (Montreal, QC)

Key Insight: Creative strategies for sustainability that can help develop new business models and foster corporate collaborations.

With its distinctive approach to beekeeping, Alvéole—founded by Declan Rankin Jardin, Étienne Lapierre, and Alex McLean—is generating attention in the field of urban sustainability. Based in Montreal, this company installs beehives and bee-friendly gardens in cities worldwide, providing businesses with a concrete opportunity to enhance biodiversity and promote environmental awareness.

Beyond beekeeping, Alvéole offers a wide range of services. To assist businesses in engaging their workers and show their dedication to sustainability, they provide educational programs and team-building events based on beekeeping. In fact, Alvéole has carved out a new niche in the corporate sustainability industry thanks to its fresh strategy.

For small business owners, Alvéole’s success demonstrates the possibilities that arise from discovering unique intersections between sustainability and business requirements. This illustrates how creative thinking can turn environmental challenges into business opportunities and how offering experiential services can differentiate a company in the B2B market.

To learn more about beekeeping technology, log onto Alvéole’s official website [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Ealveole%2Ebuzz%2F&urlhash=iRF9&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block).

Mercator AI (Calgary, AB)

Key Insight: Utilizing AI to address unique industry challenges that can result in swift progress and acceptance.

Established by Chloe Smith, Mercator AI is transforming the process of discovering and assessing new business opportunities for construction companies. In fact, their real-time intelligence platform uses artificial intelligence (AI) to improve the labour-intensive and often tedious process of identifying possible projects and leads.

What’s even better is that the company’s recent $5.1 million seed funding and expansion into multiple North American markets underscore the demand for innovative solutions in traditional industries. As such, Mercator AI’s success, which includes Smith’s recognition as the “most promising founder” at the Start Alberta Tech Awards, underscores the potential for AI-driven solutions to transform established sectors.

For entrepreneurs, Mercator AI’s journey illustrates the importance of profound industry insight paired with advanced technology. This demonstrates how focusing on solving specific, high-value problems for a particular industry can lead to rapid technology adoption and growth.

The innovative character of these businesses propels Canada’s small business sector forward. They demonstrate that tiny enterprises can have considerable influence and attain exceptional development by adopting technology, tackling environmental issues, and rethinking conventional sectors.

To learn more about Mercator AI’s solutions, visit their official website [here](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Emercator%2Eai%2F&urlhash=ccmJ&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block).

To our readers: Jubilating with these innovative companies during Small Business Month, we urge you to draw inspiration from their journeys. So, whether you’re an aspiring entrepreneur or an established business owner, these stories demonstrate the endless possibilities for innovation and growth in Canada’s dynamic business landscape.

For more inspiring stories and valuable insights to help your business thrive, [subscribe](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcanadiansme%2Eca%2Fsubscription%2F&urlhash=KF_K&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) to CanadianSME Small Business Magazine. results.content: # Canada's small business owners struggle with economic uncertainty Small business ambitions held back by economic uncertainty Only 17% of Australian small businesses plan to expand internationally, with new Xero research showing most owners are stopping short of global growth as confidence remains fragile. Small business ambitions held back by economic uncertainty Only 17% of Australian small businesses plan to expand internationally, with new Xero research showing most owners are stopping short of global growth as confidence remains fragile. Small businesses are the backbone of our economy, and it's inspiring to see recent initiatives aimed at supporting their growth! Share your own insights or experiences with small business growth in the comments below.
results.raw_content:
# Canada's small business owners struggle with economic uncertainty

This title was summarized by AI from the post below.

[Sasha Boersma](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/sashaboersma?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

Co-Founder/Producer, Sticky Brain Studios | Board of Directors, Disability Screen Office | Women in Games Ambassador

* [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

Your industry's small business owners in Canada are not doing ok. Look beyond the headlines of economic 'resilience' and talk to small business owners - Canada's in trouble. There is collective denial about the economic reality of entrepreneurship. Consumer spending is down. Austerity practices by those who have the money limits cash flow to consumers. Housing costs have a stranglehold on much of the population which impacts discretionary spending. Then trying to operate during global uncertainty with the bonus of investors (if your sector even has those) being cautious and pulling back... Unfortunately for us, it feels like Canada (including the provinces) is doing the typical thing going - if the big companies are ok, we'll be ok. On one hand, makes sense, in theory they will keep and generate the most jobs. But did anyone notice during the pandemic, how little money flowed out to employees from large companies? The volume of CEWS that then went into shareholder dividends instead of actual wages. The huge wage and bonus discrepancies between the executive class to their workforce. The mass layoffs that happened anyways? Small businesses employ close to 40% of Canadians. Small business leadership operates much closer to our employees and our customers. But now it feels like sustainable growth is impossible. We need new ideas. But we are all too tired of doing this ourselves to come up with those ideas. Colleagues who have reached out for help get financial lessons  when managing finances is not the problem. There is no shareholder value calculation that is going to inspire us out of the depression. It feels like, as a business owner, that we dont have any choice but to keep slogging through. It's not like we can quit our businesses and collect EI because we are not eligible for EI as a business owner. Maybe find another job? Unfortunately we see our peers struggling for employment right now. Many of us had a back-up through contract teaching at post-secondary institutions, but due to irresponsible government behaviours most of us have lost that too. Everyone else tells us how they are taking on the risk of our business for any number of reasons¦ but no one seems to want to recognize the risk small business owners take, and how we are left with nothing while large businesses with their investors keep floating along with increasing government support. The conventional advice is that we just need to business better. But we have businessed. We have businessed plans A, B, C, L, M, X, Y, Z and are now on plan AZ or 12M. Its the everything else going on around us that we cant control. The large entities that mislead us into bad business deals. The investors that say were too risky. The supply chain that has turned upside down. The increasing loss of consumer spending power. And the feeling that we cant talk about any of this, because social and economic systems are designed as though the small business owners are the failures.

[39](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_social-actions-reactions)   [16 Comments](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_social-actions-comments)

[Like](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_like-cta)   [Comment](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment-cta)

[Denis Coyne](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/denisjcoyne?trk=public_post_comment_actor-name)   1mo 

* [Report this comment](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=COMMENT&_f=guest-reporting)

100%. Long story short, Ive recently navigated municipal bureaucracy around building permits. It was eye opening and infuriating. Im still traumatized. Its a real barrier to small business. I was trapped for 8 months. Thats measurable as % of my lifespan. I survived by the kindness of my skilled friends saving me tens of thousands¦ Rules and regs are importabt for safety, yes, but the systems weve built around them dont work. They punish people for trying to do it right. The people inside the systems are punished too. They avoid decisions because in that there is job safety. They dont help anyone unless its off the record, but there are barriers to even reaching them for direct communication. This isnt a system that benefits the economy. It definitely stifles small business. Now when I see a chain store on a corner I know why. They have more money, deeper pockets, and pay their way through it all via expensive consultants  or they just break rules and pay fines later. That shouldnt be the norm. We should be helping small business through. last time I checked the stats were clear, small businesses are a huge portion of the GDP.

Confidence among Canadian small businesses has taken a sharp ¬ï¸ in 2025, with major implications for TO's local economy. ð Details: ð¹The Small Business Confidence Index fell to 58% optimism, ¬ï¸ 10 points from LY ð¹62% of owners say the economy is hurting operations, citing rising costs and weaker demand. ð¹Top challenge: 43.2% point to operational costs, far ahead of concerns about economic slowdowns (34.5%) or shrinking margins (22.4%). ð¹Alarmingly, the number of businesses carrying insurance dropped 24.2%, leaving many exposed at a time of heightened risk. Some businesses are adapting with nearly 39% exploring new markets but many feel squeezed by high costs, shifting demand, and policy shocks. For TO, where small businesses are vital to both employment and community vibrancy, declining confidence signals broader stress in the labour market.   Small business ambitions held back by economic uncertainty Only 17% of Australian small businesses plan to expand internationally, with new Xero research showing most owners are stopping short of global growth as confidence remains fragile. The survey of 500 entrepreneurs also found that while 83% believe Australia is a good place to start a business, fewer see the conditions to scale beyond domestic markets. That said, 48% of business owners already consider themselves successful, and another 48% believe they are on their way. But inhibitors remain, with 41% pointing to external factors such as economic conditions, 36% citing stagnant growth, and 27% highlighting access to funding as a barrier. These challenges show why many business owners hesitate to take the next step, whether thats expanding internationally or simply growing locally. Finance can play a key role in overcoming those hurdles, from improving cash flow to funding equipment or staff. With the right lending in place, however, small businesses can pursue growth on their own terms  and Lending Loop can help them secure the finance to get there. Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada
500 connections, 940 followers


About
Chuck McIntosh is a passionate entrepreneur who lives in the Vancouver area. Having spent over 3 decades rooted in the Hospitality Industry, Chuck and his business partners are sharing their passion for food and drink having opened restaurants like Pourhouse, Pizzeria Farina, Ask For Luigi, Di Beppe, Bacaro, Carlino and more on the way... Chuck has been featured in many major publications, industry magazines and international TV programs, including Business in Vancouver Magazine, BC Business Magazine, MTV, A&E’s “Legends of Bartending”, Radio Canada, Bar & Beverage Magazine, Flairbar Magazine, Imfamous Magazine, Chilled Magazine, the Food Network, and more. If you are looking for a career in the Hospitality industry, please reach out or visit www.ktrestaurants.com

# David Luis Post

[David Lui](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/davidymlui?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

Chief Executive Officer, KIT + ACE | Co-Founder, Unity Brands. Grew Up in Retail. Never Left. Now Reimagining Whats Possible.

* [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fdavidymlui_entrepreneurship-retail-canada-activity-7377743211353735169-VY1q&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

While cleaning my home office, I found a Report on Business clipping from [The Globe and Mail](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/the-globe-and-mail?trk=public_post-text), dated August 16, 1996. I was a passionate young entrepreneur with a wild idea at 18: to bring a Hong Kong fashion concept to Canada.  Over a short time opened 10 stores, 70 people, big dreams, and plenty of risk. Seeing this again reminded me of those early days  the hustle, the uncertainty, the thrill of seeing the first sale and customers walk in wearing something wed created, and the excitement of building something from nothing. That moment taught me what still drives me today: take risks early, bet on yourself, and surround yourself with great people. Retail has changed so much since then  and so have I  my career has not been linear and my passion for building brands and taking bold risks has never faded. Keep on learning. Never Give Up! [#Entrepreneurship](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fentrepreneurship&trk=public_post-text) [#Retail](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fretail&trk=public_post-text) [#Canada](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fcanada&trk=public_post-text) [#TakeRisks](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Ftakerisks&trk=public_post-text) [#LifeLongLearning](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Flifelonglearning&trk=public_post-text)

results.raw_content:
[Jake Karls](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/jake-karls-653106ba?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

Co-Founder & Rainmaker of Mid-Day Squares. || Forbes 30 Under 30 || EY Entrepreneur Of The Year Finalist x2 ||

* [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fjake-karls-653106ba_canada-entrepreneurship-cpg-activity-7183830637198331904--mAh&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

Canada has 100,000 fewer entrepreneurs, Than it did 20 years ago. Despite our population growing to 40 million. According to a study done by the BDC and UDem. We must do something about this. Entrepreneurs and small business are the lifeblood of the Canadian economy. Theyre the ones that solve problems, stimulate innovation and supply jobs. They also keep us competitive with other countries. My goal with this post is to bring together Canadians that are risk takers. We must inspire and re-ignite the spirit of entrepreneurship here in Canada. We need to start building towards a culture that embraces RISK. Canada has some of the most brilliant minds in the world. If youre interested in helping me bring together people to help ignite the spirit of entrepreneurship here, Please comment your name below or tag someone who would be good. Lets get Canada rocking. Restaurants Canada is a national, not-for-profit member-based trade association advancing the potential of Canada’s diverse and dynamic foodservice industry through member programs, research, advocacy, resources and events. Canada’s foodservice sector is a $100 billion industry that serves 22 million customers across the country every day. As the fourth-largest private-sector employer, Canadian foodservice directly employs 1.2 million people and indirectly supports another 290,000+ jobs in related industries, with $32 billion in food and beverage products purchased every year. www.restaurantscanada.org

# Restaurants Canada
The voice of foodservice | La voix des services alimentaires
Non-profit Organizations • Toronto, Ontario • 37,784 followers • 11-50 employees

## Overview
Restaurants Canada is a national, not-for-profit member-based trade association advancing the potential of Canada’s diverse and dynamic foodservice industry through member programs, research, advocacy, resources and events. Canada’s foodservice sector is a $100 billion industry that serves 22 million customers across the country every day. As the fourth-largest private-sector employer, Canadian foodservice directly employs 1.2 million people and indirectly supports another 290,000+ jobs in related industries, with $32 billion in food and beverage products purchased every year. www.restaurantscanada.org
